post_text:
April 1st is Census Day! The Census helps our government figure out how much money each state should get for important programs over the next decade. It happens every 10 years. You should count EVERYONE in your household. Filling out the Census form for your address is SAFE, CONVENIENT, AND QUICK.

You can complete your Census on a computer, tablet or smartphone. You can also complete it over the phone or by mail. If you have any questions, go to www.2020census.gov or call 844-330-2020.

THANK YOU FOR SUPPORT OF LCPS!

post_text:
Calhoun Student to Serve as Delegate at International Conference

Congratulations The Calhoun School student Chasity Talley who will serve as a delegate representing Alabama, Tuskegee, and Calhoun at the 2019 Global Youth Institute in Des Moines, Iowa on October 16-19. Chasity conducted research on conflict in the Central African Republic and wrote a research paper outlining possible solutions to resolve those issues. During the Global Youth Institute, she will present and discuss her findings with international experts and her peers, connect with other students from around the world, tour cutting-edge industrial and research facilities, and take part in symposium discussions with global leaders in science, industry, and policy. Travel, meals, and housing will be covered by the Global Youth Institute and Tuskegee University; monies for incidentals must be provided by the student.
text:
Calhoun Student to Serve as Delegate at International Conference

Congratulations The Calhoun School student Chasity Talley who will serve as a delegate representing Alabama, Tuskegee, and Calhoun at the 2019 Global Youth Institute in Des Moines, Iowa on October 16-19. Chasity conducted research on conflict in the Central African Republic and wrote a research paper outlining possible solutions to resolve those issues. During the Global Youth Institute, she will present and discuss her findings with international experts and her peers, connect with other students from around the world, tour cutting-edge industrial and research facilities, and take part in symposium discussions with global leaders in science, industry, and policy. Travel, meals, and housing will be covered by the Global Youth Institute and Tuskegee University; monies for incidentals must be provided by the student.

Community Members.

Lowndes County Public Schools and all of its schools are engaged in an ongoing continuous improvement process, of which all stakeholders are a part. The school system invites you to participate in an online survey between the dates of September 21, 2018 and October 5, 2018 as one method of reaching all stakeholders. Surveys are a means to systematically engage all stakeholders in two-way communications. They provide school leaders and teachers a view into the thinking and perceptions of our stakeholders. Click on the link below

post_text:
CONGRATULATIONS DR. DANIEL BOYD!

Dr. Daniel Boyd submitted his letter of resignation during the monthly board meeting, June 21st. to accept a position with the Alabama State Department of Education as Deputy Superintendent over the area of Curriculum and Instruction. Dr. Boyd has served Lowndes County Public Schools for 17 years, with the last 12 years as Superintendent of Schools.

The Lowndes County Public Schools Employees' wish Dr. Daniel Boyd much success in his new endeavor. Thank you Dr. Boyd for all you have done for the students, teachers, administrators, support staff, parents and the community for your tireless services to Lowndes County Public Schools. CONGRATULATIONS!!!

post_text:
Congratulations Lowndes County Public Schools!

The Calhoun and Central High Schools have met and exceeded the state graduation rate. This year's graduation rate for the school district is 91%, which exceeds the state average of 87%. Alabama's high school graduation rate is determined by the number of students entering ninth grade who complete 12th grade in a 4-year period. We salute the graduating class of 2016-2017. A big thank you to school personnel and central office administration.

Alabama's high school graduation rate is determined by the number of students entering ninth grade who complete 12th grade in a 4-year period. We salute the graduating class of 2016-2017. A big thank you to school personnel and central office administration.

post_text:
Dr. Zelia Stephens Evans established a Scholarship Trust under her Will with Regions Bank as Trustee. Funds are available to individuals pursuing a "course of study leading to an undergraduate, graduate, or postgraduate degree" and will be awarded based on financial need and educational objectives.

Application forms and guidelines are available by request no later than November 30, 2017. All completed applications must be received no later than January 19, 2018. Each applicant will receive written notification of the Committee's decision by May of 2018.

Completed Applications must be received by January 19, 2018. For an application and guidelines, please contact Regions Trust Department at 334-240-1270 or email lisa.goggans@regions.com.

post_text:
Debbie B. Rice Memorial Scholarship Application and Guidelines

Alabama Leaders of Educational Technology (ALET) announces a $10,000 scholarship will be awarded to a public high school senior enrolled in a school system with a delegate member in this organization. Seeking graduating seniors with a record of volunteerism in the community in both non-school sponsored and extracurricular school activities. The recipient must attend an accredited college/university or technical school located in the state of Alabama.

Contact your counselor at your respective high school for application and additional information.

Debbie B. Rice Memorial Scholarship Application and Guidelines

Alabama Leaders of Educational Technology (ALET) announces a $10,000 scholarship will be awarded to a public high school senior enrolled in a school system with a delegate member in this organization. Seeking graduating seniors with a record of volunteerism in the community in both non-school sponsored and extracurricular school activities. The recipient must attend an accredited college/university or technical school located in the state of Alabama.

Contact your counselor at your respective high school for application and additional information.

post_text:
Career Fair Held at LCMS

Recently, a career fair was held for the students of Fort Deposit Elementary School, Hayneville Middle School and Lowndes County Middle School. Local and national businesses talked with the students about their job fields in an effort to encourage students to explore various career options available to them in the future. Students were able to speak to a variety of professionals to learn specific details about careers such as banking, law enforcement, healthcare and small business. Guest presenters took time to share the steps they took to arrive at their career choice along with sharing responsibilities and benefits of their job. Some of the businesses in attendance included the U.S. Transportation Security Administration, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, Robinson & Associates Architecture, Inc., Bancorp, as well as several others.
text:
Career Fair Held at LCMS

Recently, a career fair was held for the students of Fort Deposit Elementary School, Hayneville Middle School and Lowndes County Middle School. Local and national businesses talked with the students about their job fields in an effort to encourage students to explore various career options available to them in the future. Students were able to speak to a variety of professionals to learn specific details about careers such as banking, law enforcement, healthcare and small business. Guest presenters took time to share the steps they took to arrive at their career choice along with sharing responsibilities and benefits of their job. Some of the businesses in attendance included the U.S. Transportation Security Administration, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, Robinson & Associates Architecture, Inc., Bancorp, as well as several others.

post_text:
65th Annual State Leadership Conference

The Alabama Future Business Leaders of America (FBLA) 65th Annual State Leadership Conference and Competition was held in Birmingham on April 7-8, 2016. Twenty students from Central High School traveled to compete against more than 2,000 students from across the state in over 66 competitive events. Orianna Gordon, a senior, placed 4th in the Computer Applications division. As a result, she will have an opportunity to compete at the national competition that will be held in Atlanta, Georgia this summer.
text:
65th Annual State Leadership Conference

The Alabama Future Business Leaders of America (FBLA) 65th Annual State Leadership Conference and Competition was held in Birmingham on April 7-8, 2016. Twenty students from Central High School traveled to compete against more than 2,000 students from across the state in over 66 competitive events. Orianna Gordon, a senior, placed 4th in the Computer Applications division. As a result, she will have an opportunity to compete at the national competition that will be held in Atlanta, Georgia this summer.

post_text:
Career Tech Students Participate in A.C.E. Competition

Recently, students from the Career Tech department of Central High School attended and participated in the Academic Competition for Excellence held at Wallace Community College-Selma. Students had an opportunity to compete in over 30 academic and skilled competitions against other students from the state of Alabama. Zykeria Rudolph received 2nd place for Keyboarding I, Kecie Middleton placed 2nd in Keyboarding II and Orianna Gordon, Alexzanderia Holcombe, and Myaira Coleman received 1st place for Team Informational Technology. Additionally, Orianna Gordon won 1st place in the T-shirt competition for the second year in a row.

Additionally, Orianna Gordon won 1st place in the T-shirt competition for the second year in a row.

post_text:
Ms. Leslie M. Clark, LDP Coordinator in cooperation with Ms. Katanga Mants, local Tuskegee, Alabama Cooperative Extension System(ACES) representative will offer a free six week leadership development workshop at Hayneville Church of Christ, 90 Commerce St. starting Thurs., Feb 4, 2016, 6:00- 8:00 pm.

Registration for this workshop is limited therefore participants must call to register at 334-548-2315. This workshop is open to all local citizens and businesses, town hall staff, churches, school system, health facilities, court house staff, banks, department of human services, Alabama family services, civic/ social clubs, professional/retiree associations, etc.

For more information, contact Ms. Katanga Mants at mantska@aces.edu

post_text:
SCHOOL BOARD MEMBERS RECOGNIZED FOR ACHIEVEMENT

The Alabama Association of School Boards' School Board Member Academy recently recognized select school board members across the state for their achievement. The Academy provides ongoing training on important education, legal and governance issues for its members. To earn various awards, school board members attend academy conferences worth a specified number of instructional hours and partiipate in core curriculum courses. Awards are based on hours earned each academy year, which begins July 1 and ends June 30. Travis Rogers reached level 1 in the Academy. He was awarded a certificate of achievement during the Lowndes County Board of Education's October 8th meeting.

In addition, School board members, Annie C. Hunter and Steve Foster achieved level 4 or Master School Board Member in a previous year. They are congratulated for continuing to develop their boardmanship skills.

post_text:
Former Calhoun Graduate receives internship!

Shanice Seawright, a 2013 graduate of The Calhoun School, will participate in an Evolutionary Medicine Research program at UCLA from June 21-August 15, 2015.

Although she will be making the Evolution of Antibiotics Resistance her major concentration, she will also be participating in the Evolution of Vascular System in implementing image analysis software to measure properties of vascular networks from angiographic images.

All of her expenses (airfare, room and board, & meals) are covered through the program. In addition to these expenses being covered, she will also receive a $3,000 stipend for participating.

post_text:
Summer School Credit Recovery

Summer School Credit Recovery will take place at The Calhoun School from June 8, 2015 through July 2, 2015. Students in grades 9-12 can recover up to two credits for any core course that was failed during the school year. The cost is $75/per course. Please make payments to Lowndes County Board of Education by June 3, 2015, by 5:00 p.m. Students are asked to check with the high school counselor for eligibility and the registration form.

post_text:
Summer Bridge Program is back!

Parents, Lowndes County Public Schools is proud to be able to offer again the Summer Bridge Program. Registration is currently open to students who are enrolled and will be enrolled in LCPS. The dates of the program are June 8-30, 2015, Monday-Thursday, 8:00 a.m. to 1:00 p.m. The program will be held at Jackson-Steele Elementary, Hayneville Middle and Lowndes Middle Schools. You may pick up an application at either school, but the application must be hand-delivered to the central office no later than May 15, 2015 by 5:00 p.m. Space is limited and is on a first come basis. Students will be provided transportation, breakfast and lunch daily. WE LOOK FORWARD TO ANOTHER EXCITING SUMMER!

post_text:
Central High School Mission Statement

Central High School’s mission is to prepare students to become responsible citizens, effective communicators, lifelong learners, and “fierce competitors on the economic world stage.” Our intent is to encourage students as they explore horizons, challenge obstacles, and establish independence. We shall foster literacy, develop communities, and enrich the academic environment.

Central High School Mission Statement

We shall foster literacy, develop communities, and enrich the academic environment.

post_text:
Central Elementary School's Creed

I am a Central Elementary School student. I believe in myself and all I can do. I can accomplish my goals and you should too! I respect myself and all the rest. I will conduct myself to do my best. I can set my mind to do anything. I can achieve my goals with the power I bring. I will learn all I need to grow and succeed!

I can set my mind to do anything. I can achieve my goals with the power I bring. I will learn all I need to grow and succeed!

post_text:
Lowndes County Middle School Mission

The mission of Lowndes County Middle School is to be a community-nuturing academic environment of excellence for all students and to demonstrate leadership in character development. Lowndes County Middle School is committed to providing an educational environment in which all students can and will learn to become responsible citizens and will be “fierce competitors on the economic world stage.”

Jackson-Steele Elementary School

The mission of Jackson-Steele Elementary is to assure that students are responsible, self-assured productive citizens who possess a desire for learning and a respect for self and others. To provide a wholesome environment where dedicated staff members utilize a flexible curriculum relevant to the needs of the students.

post_text:
The Calhoun School

The mission of The Calhoun School is to foster nourishing growth and the sound development of each individual academically and emotionally who will thereby be prepared to intensely compete in a global society. We will create a safe and extraordinary place to learn and excel. This will be accomplished by a well-trained staff, utilizing a technologically sound, student centered curriculum.
